title: How to Stop Biting Your Nails
description: Start by becoming aware of the behavior. What mood accompanies the biting? Are you more likely to chew in certain rooms?
content: “Learn to resist the urge,” says Tara S. Peris, an associate professor of psychiatry and biobehavioral sciences at the University of California, Los Angeles, where she is co-director of the Child O.C.D., Anxiety and Tic Disorders Program. Psychiatrists consider nail biting a “body focused repetitive behavior,” along with things like hair pulling and skin picking. Nail biting tends to begin in childhood and adolescence, but researchers estimate that as much as 30 percent of Americans are chronic nail biters. Often a form of self-soothing, the disorder can, over time, disrupt the functioning of a brain’s reward circuitry. An occasional nibble probably isn’t concerning, but if you gnaw until you injure yourself — if your fingers are bloody or infected — or if the biting distracts or shames you, you should know that you can get help.

description: The actor discussed her Emmy nomination for playing Wendy Byrde on “Ozark,” which tied with HBO’s “Succession” this year for the most nods of any drama.
content: Netflix’s “Ozark” became the go-to watch for many Americans stuck in their homes during quarantine — and now it’s netted 18 Emmy nominations, tied for the most of any drama with HBO’s “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

description: A selection of recent poetry books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: THE CLEARING: Poems, by Allison Adair. (Milkweed, $22.) The poems in Adair’s debut draw on folklore and the animal world to assert feminist viewpoints and mortal terror in lush musical lines, as when “A fat speckled spider sharpens / in the shoe of someone you need.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang, Jack Nicas and David McCabe
title: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google Prepare for Their ‘Big Tobacco Moment’
description: The tech C.E.O.s will appear together at a congressional hearing on Wednesday to argue that their companies do not stifle competition.
content: WASHINGTON — After lawmakers collected hundreds of hours of interviews and obtained more than 1.3 million documents about Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google, their chief executives will testify before Congress on Wednesday to defend their powerful businesses from the hammer of government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noemie Nakai
title: Have You Considered the Benefits of Crying?
description: A teacher travels across Japan to encourage adults to cry more.
content: It’s safe to say we all have more to cry about this year. Gone, for the most part, are the days when shedding tears around other people was derided as inappropriate or embarrassing: Even leaders are crying in public. And that’s OK: Crying can be really, really good for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Brody
title: Why It’s Good to Be Old, Even in a Pandemic
description: That aging can make us better than ever may be the biggest dirty little secret of all time.
content: Eight out of every 10 deaths from the coronavirus pandemic reported in the United States have happened to adults 65 and older, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. So you could be forgiven for concluding this is a lousy time to be over 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Oster
title: What Will Schools Do When a Teacher Gets Covid-19?
description: Cases are inevitable. Schools need to plan now.
content: The logistics of reopening schools are daunting. Plans are full of details about which days kids will be eligible for, and pages and pages on preventing students and staffs from getting sick. What kind of limits will be placed on class sizes? What kind of cleaning? Will there be symptom checks or temperature screens? Masks for everyone or just adults?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Emmys: Jeremy Pope Is Glad He Took a Chance on ‘Hollywood’
description: The Broadway veteran received an Emmy nomination for his TV debut, in the revisionist Netflix series. “I cried this morning,” he said. “It’s like feeling seen from a new group of people.”
content: Jeremy Pope’s first foray into television — in “Hollywood,” Ryan Murphy’s revisionist Tinseltown melodrama on Netflix — has been the stuff Hollywood dreams are made of. On Tuesday, Pope received his first Emmy nomination for his role as Archie, a gay Black screenwriter who sells a script about Peggy Entwistle, an obscure aspiring actress who gained notoriety in 1932 when she jumped to her death from the Hollywood sign (which then read “Hollywoodland”) at age 24. Pope was listed alongside veterans like Jeremy Irons, Hugh Jackman and Mark Ruffalo in the stacked category of best actor in a limited series or movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Kiernan
title: A Forgotten Town at the Center of the Manhattan Project
description: In “The Apocalypse Factory,” Steve Olson tells the story of Hanford, a small rural town in Washington State that played an outsize role in America’s nuclear ambitions.
content: THE APOCALYPSE FACTORY Plutonium and the Making of the Atomic AgeBy Steve Olson

content: The cliché of the volatile chef riding roughshod over his subordinates receives a thorough airing in “Nose to Tail,” a resolute but finally punishing wallow in self-destructiveness and obnoxious male behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Despite Evidence, Park Police Chief Says ‘Tremendous Restraint’ Was Used in Lafayette Clash
description: Lawmakers repeatedly pressed Gregory T. Monahan to square his remarks with videos showing his officers attacking protesters. He declined.
content: WASHINGTON — Confronted by lawmakers multiple times with videos of Park Police officers advancing on protesters and beating reporters in Lafayette Square last month, Gregory T. Monahan, the force’s acting chief, refused on Tuesday to acknowledge the violent clashes and testified that his officers acted with “tremendous restraint.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Rhiannon Giddens to Lead Silkroad’s Musical Explorations
description: A folk virtuoso will be the artistic director of the cross-cultural exchange organization founded by Yo-Yo Ma.
content: Trained as an opera singer, Rhiannon Giddens was a founding member of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, the acclaimed folk group. With the Chocolate Drops and as a solo artist, a virtuoso fiddler and banjo player with a soulful voice, she has delved into African-American and old-time traditions. She won a MacArthur “genius” grant in 2017 and wrote an opera based on the autobiography of Omar Ibn Said, a Muslim man from Africa who was enslaved in South Carolina. (Its planned premiere has been delayed until next year by the coronavirus pandemic.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Emily Cochrane
title: ‘I Just Don’t Get It’: Republicans Balk at Funding F.B.I. Building in Virus Bill
description: Another chapter in President Trump’s quest to shape the future of the J. Edgar Hoover Building seemed over as Republicans distanced themselves from the administration’s $1.75 billion demand.
content: WASHINGTON — Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Senate majority leader, looked startled on Monday when first asked why Republicans had agreed to a White House demand that $1.75 billion for a new F.B.I. building be tucked into their emergency coronavirus relief bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Chainsmokers Concert in Hamptons Is Under Fire Over Social Distancing
description: The state’s health commissioner opened an inquiry after video footage of the concert showed crowds of people standing close together.
content: A charity concert on Saturday night in the Hamptons featuring performances from the chief executive of Goldman Sachs and the D.J. duo the Chainsmokers drew widespread outrage and a state investigation after video footage showed attendees appearing to ignore public health precautions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Misleading Virus Video, Pushed by the Trumps, Spreads Online
description: Social media companies took down the video within hours. But by then, it had already been viewed tens of millions of times.
content: In a video posted Monday online, a group of people calling themselves “America’s Frontline Doctors” and wearing white medical coats spoke against the backdrop of the Supreme Court in Washington, sharing misleading claims about the virus, including that hydroxychloroquine was an effective coronavirus treatment and that masks did not slow the spread of the virus.

title: Netflix Breaks HBO’s Record for the Most Emmy Nominations Ever
description: “Watchmen” earned 26 nominations, the most of any show, and the Television Academy gave newcomers Disney+ and Apple TV+ their first nods.
content: Netflix dominated the 72nd Emmy Award nominations on Tuesday, breaking the record for the most nominations ever, and a newcomer to the streaming universe, Disney+, scored a nomination in a big category for “The Mandalorian” in yet another sign of the growing importance of digital technology to Hollywood.

author: By Kate Manne
title: Women Can Have a Little Power, as a Treat
description: A female vice president would be tasked with wielding power in the service of a more powerful man. That’s no challenge to the patriarchy.
content: For those of us who believe that a female president is long overdue, the past few years have been bitterly disappointing. From Hillary Clinton’s surprise loss to Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election to the failure of the Democratic Party to choose a female candidate this year despite an abundance of qualified women, it’s been one setback after another. And though there’s abundant evidence that women can win elections in lower races, a slim majority of American men, and just over 40 percent of American women, still aren’t “very comfortable” with the idea of a female president.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Folklore’: Let’s Discuss
description: On an album made entirely in quarantine, the singer and songwriter embarks in a fresh direction.
content: Taylor Swift released her eighth album, “Folklore,” last week; created wholly during the quarantine, it marks a new musical direction for the singer-songwriter. Working primarily with Aaron Dessner of the National, Swift moved away from the pop explosions of her last few albums and toward an album laden with indie rock and art-folk gestures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: ‘Amazing, Isn’t It?’ Long-Sought Blood Test for Alzheimer’s in Reach
description: Scientists say such tests could be available in a few years, speeding research for treatments and providing a diagnosis for dementia patients who want to know if they have Alzheimer’s disease.
content: A newly developed blood test for Alzheimer’s has diagnosed the disease as accurately as methods that are far more expensive or invasive, scientists reported on Tuesday, a significant step toward a longtime goal for patients, doctors and dementia researchers. The test has the potential to make diagnosis simpler, more affordable and widely available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Senate Democrats Issue Scathing Review of Pompeo’s Tenure at State Dept.
description: The report, which describes vacant key posts and a culture of disrespect and political retaliation, came days before Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will give long-awaited testimony on Capitol Hill.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats unveiled a report Tuesday highly critical of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s management of the State Department, two days before he is set to testify on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Megan Thee Stallion Gives New Details in Account of Shooting
description: Neither the rapper nor the police have named anyone as responsible for causing her injuries.
content: The rapper Megan Thee Stallion gave new details on Instagram this week in her account of being shot in Los Angeles this month, saying she was struck in both feet and that “fake stories” about her injuries continued to spread online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: House Votes to Create a National Museum of the American Latino
description: Plans for a museum devoted to the history and contributions of Latinos in the United States began forming in the 2000s, but legislation had not gained traction in Congress until now.
content: Supporters of a National Museum of the American Latino are the closest they have ever been to gaining a spot on the National Mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Florida Man Took Coronavirus Aid and Bought a Lamborghini, Officials Say
description: David T. Hines, 29, was arrested and charged with three felonies after spending relief money on the $318,497 car, clothes and jewelry, federal prosecutors said.
content: A man in Florida who received nearly $4 million in federal loans intended to help struggling businesses — and spent the money on a new Lamborghini Huracán sports car and other fraudulent purchases — was arrested and charged with three felonies, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Beta
title: Eddie Chacon, a Fleeting ’90s Neo Soul Star, Returns as an Old Soul
description: As one-half of Charles & Eddie, he had an international hit with “Would I Lie to You?” Now he’s releasing his first music in decades.
content: The year was 1992, and a longhaired Eddie Chacon, in suspenders and big hoop earrings, grinned and posed alongside Charles Pettigrew in the video for “Would I Lie to You?” The duo took turns singing in silky falsetto — the pop-soul song’s memorable chorus is “Look into my eyes, can’t you see they’re open wide?/Would I lie to you, baby, would I lie to you?” — and occasionally Chacon let out a triumphant, soaring “Hoo!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: What Will a Post-Trump G.O.P. Look Like?
description: And consider, what will it take for the Republican Party to begin to heal itself?
content: If Donald Trump stages another come-from-behind victory in November — helped, in all likelihood, by the collapse of public order in American cities — the Republican Party will become an oddity for the Trump Organization: the only entity it owns but does not brand. Not only will Trump remain in office for another term, but the Trumpers will also dominate the G.O.P. for another generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Duplex Sells for Almost $100 Million at 220 Central Park South
description: The condo, at the pinnacle of the limestone tower, is the year’s most expensive sale. It was one of three big purchases there during July.
content: A sprawling penthouse on the top two floors of 220 Central Park South sold for $99.9 million in July, becoming the year’s most expensive closing in New York City, although overall sales volume continued to slow because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: After Quitting Deadspin in Protest, They’re Starting a New Site
description: The journalists who took part in a staff rebellion last year are starting Defector Media, a company with a podcast and a website dedicated to sports and culture.
content: One of the biggest staff rebellions in online media took place last year, when all of the journalists working at the irreverent, sports-centric website Deadspin resigned in protest after clashing with their bosses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Report Slams Doctor at V.A. for Dismissing Suicide Risk of Patient Who Later Killed Himself
description: Six days after being removed by the police from a veterans hospital in Washington, the man died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.
content: WASHINGTON — The internal watchdog for the Department of Veterans Affairs said Tuesday that a veteran who came through the department’s medical center in Washington last year seeking psychiatric treatment died by suicide a few days later, after a doctor there ordered him forcibly removed and was heard saying that she did “not care” if he killed himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: New Census Worry: A Rushed Count Could Mean a Botched One
description: Stalled by the pandemic, the count is supposed to resume soon. But census experts are rattled by signs of a push from the White House to finish it early.
content: WASHINGTON — As the 2020 census struggles to find its footing amid the coronavirus outbreak and public reluctance to give the government personal data, officials have a new worry: The Trump administration and Senate Republicans appear to be signaling that they want the census finished well ahead of schedule, pandemic or not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Newman
title: These Celebrities Can Change Your Life
description: From big picture advice to helpful hints, survivors of the spotlight have some words of wisdom for you.
content: When considering self-help books by celebrities, I look first at what expertise the author has that qualifies him or her to be dispensing advice. So what to do with HUSTLE HARDER, HUSTLE SMARTER (Amistad, 304 pp., $27.99), by Curtis Jackson, the rapper/producer/actor/entrepreneur known as 50 Cent? I don’t need advice on selling drugs (Fiddy at age 12), getting shot (nine times) or making hit records (over 30 million albums sold). But it happens the man has made several fortunes (and lost a couple too), which makes “Hustle Harder” an inspirational, if at times alarming, read. Like Snoop Dogg, Jackson’s got his mind on his money, and his money on his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

description: He joined Ted Turner to create the Cable News Network and oversaw its growth before being fired. Afterward he was critical of how CNN had changed.

content: WASHINGTON — From the earliest days of the recent protests against police brutality and racism, some top federal law enforcement officials viewed the demonstrators with alarm and called for an aggressive federal response that two months later continues to escalate.

title: ‘This Is About Justice’: Biden Ties Economic Revival to Racial Equity
description: In the last of four proposals laying out his vision for economic recovery, Joseph R. Biden Jr. pledged to lift up minority-owned businesses and to award them more federal contracts.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. unveiled wide-ranging plans on Tuesday to address systemic racism in the nation’s economy, saying this year’s election was about “understanding people’s struggles” and pledging to tear down barriers for minority-owned businesses.

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: John Saxon, a Star of ‘Enter the Dragon,’ Is Dead at 83
description: A son of Brooklyn whose “smoldering” good looks got him to Hollywood, where he once starred with Marlon Brando and, by Mr. Saxon’s lights, outacted him.
content: John Saxon, who skipped school one day as a teenager and stumbled into a long film and television career that included recurring roles on “Falcon Crest” and other series and a featured role opposite Bruce Lee in the martial-arts classic “Enter the Dragon” in 1973, died on Saturday in Brentwood, Tenn. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: A Clue to Van Gogh’s Final Days Is Found in His Last Painting
description: A researcher says he has uncovered the precise location where the artist painted “Tree Roots,” thought to be the last piece he worked on the day he suffered a fatal gunshot wound.
content: AMSTERDAM — One hundred and thirty years ago, Vincent van Gogh awoke in his room at an inn in Auvers-sur-Oise, France, and went out, as he usually did, with a canvas to paint. That night, he returned to the inn with a fatal gunshot wound. He died two days later, on July 29, 1890.

title: Too Much Mars? Let’s Discuss Other Worlds

content: Three government space agencies around the world are getting ready to return to Mars this summer. Along with China and the United Arab Emirates, the United States plans to land the fifth NASA rover, Perseverance, on the red planet (along with a small, experimental helicopter, Ingenuity). description: Whether he is dealing with the loss of a family member or the deaths of nearly 150,000 Americans in a surging pandemic, President Trump almost never displays empathy in public. He learned it from his father.
content: WASHINGTON — The Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan was packed with developers, politicians and New York celebrities, more than 600 in all, for the funeral of Fred C. Trump, the builder whose no-frills brick rental towers transformed Brooklyn and Queens.

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia Says Chinese Students Are Targets in ‘Virtual Kidnapping’ Scams
description: Recent cases reveal the evolution of a crime that often exploits worry over family members abroad with digital savvy and old-fashioned coercion.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — The young woman’s parents in China believed the video was real. It seemed to show their 21-year-old daughter pleading for help somewhere in Australia. She had been out of touch for days. She looked to be in pain, and the perpetrators pointed to only one solution: a six-figure ransom payment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: Livestream Your Wedding Like a Pro

content: A smartphone with a strong internet connection is the only tool you really need to livestream a wedding to your friends and family. But if you want to heighten your production quality, and pull off a memorable livestream for your digital guests, you’ll need some extra gadgets.

content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Attorney General William P. Barr forcefully defended the federal response to long-running protests in Portland on Tuesday, telling the House Judiciary Committee that the protests had become violent. author: By Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
title: ‘City Dreamers’ Review: The Female Architects Who Laid the Blueprint
description: The documentarian Joseph Hillel chronicles the lives of four brilliant women who helped pave the way in a male-dominated field.
content: The four architects in “City Dreamers” — Phyllis Lambert, Denise Scott Brown, Cornelia Hahn Oberlander and Blanche Lemco van Ginkel — have distinct specializations, but they’re connected by their humanitarian aspirations and by their experiences in a male-dominated industry. Having begun their careers after World War II, the four found themselves the rare, if not sole, women in their respective schools. Once they graduated, they were often underestimated and overlooked. Yet, they persevered.

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Four of the World’s Wealthiest Men Are Preparing for Battle
description: Members of Congress will be able to grill tech C.E.O.s at a hearing. Let’s hope they don’t waste the opportunity.
content: Amid the coronavirus pandemic, Congress’s attention will turn briefly to another matter: world domination. On Wednesday, the chief executives of Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google’s parent company, Alphabet, will appear together to defend themselves in a continuing inquiry into their market power by the congressional subcommittee focused on antitrust.
source.name: The New York Times

content: ELSA, Texas — Johnny Salinas Jr., the owner of Salinas Funeral Home, typically handles five funerals a week. But on a recent day, with the coronavirus tearing through his community, he saw that many grieving families in a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
